title: 111_hr2241
content: The Act titled "Equitable Compensation for American Victims of Torture Act of 2009" aims to provide justice for victims of torture and terrorism. The Congress finds that during the Gulf War in 1991, Americans serving in the Armed Forces and CBS News reporter Bob Simon were captured, tortured, and subjected to horrendous acts by Saddam Hussein's regime. Many US citizens were detained and beaten following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. Following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, many US citizens were detained, beaten, and used as "human shields" by Iraq to prevent military intervention. The Department of State had classified Iraq as a state sponsor of terrorism at that time. American POWs and civilian hostages suffered long-term physical, emotional, and mental damage. During the Gulf War, American POWs and civilian hostages endured brutal torture and terrorism, resulting in long-term physical and emotional damage. Upon their return, they were welcomed as heroes by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. Congress passed resolutions condemning Iraq's treatment of captured US service members. In 1996, Congress passed an amendment allowing torture victims like American POWs to seek compensation from terrorist countries like Iraq under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. The American Gulf War POWs sought compensation for their injuries from Iraq by filing claims in the United States District Court for damages related to their torture and abuse. The American Gulf War POWs, including military personnel from various branches, sought compensation for their injuries from Iraq through legal claims in the United States District Court. In 2003, former American Gulf War POWs were awarded damages for torture by Iraq, but have not received payment due to legal obstacles. In 2003, former American Gulf War POWs were awarded damages for torture by Iraq but have not received payment. They are unable to pursue their claims in US courts due to a waiver granted for Iraq by the President under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008. In 2003, former American Gulf War POWs were awarded damages for torture by Iraq. The President directed the payment of judgments from blocked Iraqi accounts and confiscated remaining assets for Iraq reconstruction. The plaintiffs in Vine v. Republic of Iraq, over 200 US citizens held hostage in Iraq, have pending claims in a US district court. They have not been compensated and cannot enforce any judgment due to a waiver granted by the President for Iraq. The United States courts may not provide compensation for American POWs due to a waiver granted for Iraq by the President. The Third Geneva Convention prohibits absolving Iraq of liability for torture of prisoners of war. The US has a moral obligation to protect. The United States has a moral obligation to protect its Armed Forces and citizens from torture and hostage-taking, holding state sponsors of terrorism accountable. Adequate settlement of certain cases against Iraq must be reached within a 30-day period. Adequate settlement of cases against Iraq must be reached within a 30-day period, or the waiver authority granted to the President will terminate. Adequate settlement of cases against Iraq must be reached within a 30-day period, or the waiver authority granted to the President, shall terminate. Cases numbered 99:00CV03346 (TPJ), 1:01CV02674 (HHK), CIV.A. 02-632 (RWR) (July 7, 2003), 1:03CV00691 (HHK), 1:03CV00888 (HHK), and No. 03-0215 (JDB) in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia are included. Adequate settlement means payment by the Government of Iraq or a United States depository institution of specified amounts. An unqualified guarantee of at least $150,000, plus $6,000 per day held hostage, is provided to individuals with claims arising from hostage situations who have not obtained a judgment before the enactment of this Act. An unqualified guarantee of $150,000, plus $6,000 per day held hostage, is provided to individuals with claims from hostage situations, not exceeding $900,000 in total. The Act guarantees $2,500,000 plus $6,000 per day for hostages subjected to torture who have not obtained a judgment before the enactment date. Spouses or children of qualifying individuals receive one-third of the amount. The Act guarantees $2,500,000 plus $6,000 per day for hostages subjected to torture who have not obtained a judgment before the enactment date. Spouses or children of qualifying individuals receive one-third of the amount. For those who obtained a judgment before the enactment date, they will receive payment of the unsatisfied amount, up to $1,000,000. The term "hostage" refers to an individual in hostage status or seized during an act of hostage taking. "Hostage status" is defined as being in a hostage situation. The term "person" includes the legal representative of a claimant's estate in cases of hostage taking. The term "person" in cases of hostage taking includes the legal representative of a claimant's estate. The term "torture" and "United States" are defined in specific sections of the law. The term "United States depository institution" refers to a depository institution organized under the laws of any State, the District of Columbia, or the United States. Additionally, Section 1503 of the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2003, and any exercise of appropriations act provision are covered in the text. The Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act of 2003 did not authorize the removal of jurisdiction over cases under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 also did not allow for the removal of jurisdiction. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008, under section 1083(d), did not intend to remove jurisdiction over cases brought under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. Section 1083(c) of the NDAA applies to cases specified in subsection (b)(2) regardless of any waiver for Iraq.
